column4: can anyone help me with vi (vim) i am unable to delete line feeds.   when i'm backspacing and hit column 1 i cannot go up the the next line, and i cannot use the delete key either     i have used vi/vim on many distros and never had any trouble with it except in ubuntu 9.10
you probably only have vim-tiny installed, which is default I believe, you probably want either vim-nox or vim-gnome installed
perhaps, but i wonder why a proper vi install doesn't come in the distro?   currently it is literally impossible to delete a line feed using vi
because only so much fits in the default install, and the default command line text editor is actually nano
all you need to do is sudo aptitude install vim-nox
ok, i just wish i could have a proper teminal editor before i get online (as it takes some doing to get this computer online)   i've never had problem with past ubuntus or other distros

if vim-nox is really what i need to be able to erase line feeds then i would highly suggest (to any powers that be) that the 2 megabyte program be included on the live disk (which i know had 2 megs free)
jta
i have vim-common installed, is that not good enough ( i also have vim-tiny)
vim-common isn't the binary, you only have vim-tiny

synaptic shows vim-common as installed, when i apt-get install vim-common it says it's already installed; so perhaps this is another problem I have?    another interesting this is that vi (the one that comes installed on the distro) work on my other computer, but not here, which makes me suspect a configuation problem with the keyboard possibly
you want vim-nox, or vim-gnome
I've always encountered that with vim-tiny, it acts more like original vi
i don't have vim-nox installed on my other computer and it works; so i don't believe that i do need it
vim-nox also gives you the fully featured vim, vim-tiny is quite crippled in comparison
do you know what vim-common is?
it's all the bits that are common to all forms of the binary
for example: vim-tiny, vim-nox, vim-gnome, there are others too I think
those give you the binary compiled with more or less options
and possibly additional files necessary for that version
ok, vim-nox is working for me; thanks       sorry if i seem frustrated, it's because i am :)    i'd really like a proper terminal editor for use before i get online
